data.name: GuiAcceptText
data.value:
This tool is offered as a free utility to assess your Veeam Configuration. It is offered "at your own risk".

The tool will engage PowerShell and SQL to gather data and then output files and folders to local disk.

The files may be anonymized to hide sensitive data. Accepting the Terms means that the user agrees to execute this program in its full capacity.

data.name: GuiInstCaveat1
data.value: * If opted to remove sensitive data types, only HTML report will be cleansed. See:

data.name: GuiInstCaveat2
data.value: ** Note, in larger environments, this tool can take up to 3 hours to complete.

data.name: GuiInstLine3
data.value: 3. Upon completion, Windows Explorer will open to the output directory. (If enabled, HTML report will be shown)

data.name: GuiInstLine5
data.value: 5. Capture output from C:\\temp\\vHC* - or whichever directory was specified.

data.name: GuiInstLine6
data.value: 6. Notify your Veeam SE and/or send them the results for review

data.name: GuiSensData
data.value: Remove sensitive data types from report

data.name: PlHdrTT1
data.value: Total VMware VMs found with backups

data.name: PlHdrTT2
data.value: Total VMwar VMs found with no backups

data.name: PlHdrTT4
data.value: VMs backed up via Agents as physical workloads

data.name: PlHdrTT5
data.value: Total count of servers added into Protection Groups

data.name: PlHdrTT6
data.value: Total count of servers with backups

data.name: PlHdrTT7
data.value: Total count of servers in a Protection Group but with no current backups

data.name: PlSum1
data.value: This table summarizes the amount of workloads detected in the current backup server. The VMware (Vi Total) count is determined by the local Veeam Broker service and compares that VM count with the existing backups. The physical workloads (Phys Total) are determined by the number of VMs added to Protection Groups and then compared to what is in backup jobs.

data.name: PlNote1
data.value: "Duplicates" shows the discrepancy between unique workloads in backup jobs and those workloads across multiple backup jobs as may be reflected in the VMC file. It does not mean VM's (or their license consumption) is being duplicated.

data.name: HtmlHeader
data.value: Veeam Backup & Recovery Health Check Report

data.name: HtmlSecurityHeader
data.value: Veeam Backup & Recovery Health Check Security Report

data.name: HtmlIntroLine1
data.value: The Veeam Health Check Report report provides data and insight into your Veeam Backup and Replication (VBR) deployment. The information provided here is intended to be used in collaboration with your Veeam representative.

data.name: HtmlIntroLine2
data.value: The raw data is captured in CSV format and is accessible locally in the Export Folder. CSV will let you manipulate the data in tools such as Excel.

data.name: HtmlIntroLine3Original
data.value: Additional information on individual job sessions can be found in the output folder at C:\\temp\\vHC\\Original\\JobSessionReports

data.name: HtmlIntroLine3Anon
data.value: Additional information on individual job sessions can be found in the output folder at C:\\temp\\vHC\\Anonymous\\JobSessionReports

data.name: HtmlIntroLine4
data.value: During mouseover, a tool tip may appear containing explanatory data of the table header or data column.

data.name: HtmlIntroLine5
data.value: The tool you ran to generate this report is completely self-contained, does not ‘phone-home’ and was only executed on your Veeam Backup and Replication server. It queries the VBR database, registry, configuration and log files. It does not require access to vCenter or any other infrastructure.

data.name: HtmlIntroLine5vb365
data.value: NOTE: The tool you ran to generate this report is completely self-contained, does not ‘phone-home’ and was only executed on your Veeam Backup for Microsoft 365 server. It queries the VB365 database, registry, configuration and log files. It does not require access to M365 or any other infrastructure.

data.name: NavBkpSrvDeet
data.value: Detailed information on the Backup Server, Configuration DB, roles, and resources.

data.name: NavJobConDeet
data.value: Heatmap showing max job concurrency found per hour.

data.name: NavJobSessSumDeet
data.value: Summary of job sessions by job name.

data.name: NavJobSumDeet
data.value: Summary of found jobs by type and count.

data.name: NavMissingDeet
data.value: Displays workloads and types that are not utilized.

data.name: NavProtWkldDeet
data.value: Shows count of detected VM & Physical objects compared to objects with backups.

data.name: NavProxyDeet
data.value: Details on proxy resources and config.

data.name: NavRegKeyDeet
data.value: Shows any registry values differing from a vanilla install.

data.name: NavRepoDeet
data.value: Details on non-SOBR repositories, resources, and config.

data.name: NavSecSumDeet
data.value: Brief table showing security features in use.

data.name: NavSobrDeet
data.value: Summary of SOBRs and config options.

data.name: NavSobrExtDeet
data.value: Details on SOBR Extents, resources, and config.

data.name: NavSrvInfoDeet
data.value: List of all servers added into the configuration by the user.

data.name: NavSrvSumDeet
data.value: Summary of detected infrastructure types and counts.

data.name: NavTaskConDeet
data.value: Heatmap showing max VM concurrency found per hour.

data.name: NpButton
data.value: Show details on missing job types

data.name: NpSum1
data.value: This table summarizes job types that are either missing from your configuration or could not be analyzed. Please consult with your Veeam Engineer for more information.

data.name: SSHdrTT0
data.value: Is immutability being used anywhere in this server?

data.name: SSSum1
data.value: The Security Summary Table provides an at-a-glance view of which security features are enabled on one or more components within your B&R Configuration. A value of "false" may be an area for remediation.

data.name: SSNote1
data.value: For immutable backups, consider deploying a Hardened Linux Repository or choose a Public Cloud or S3-Compatible option that offers immutability.

data.name: SSNote2
data.value: Traffic Encryption is enabled for all public traffic by default. If this value shows as false, consider re-enabling the setting for Internet or any other potentially sensitive transfers.

data.name: SSNote3
data.value: Backup File Encryption prevents outsiders from importing your backups and having access to the contents. If backups are stored offsite, consider enabling Backup File Encryption to protect the backups from unwanted access.

data.name: SSNote4
data.value: The Configuration Backup ensures your B&R configuration is backed up and ready to restore in the event of an outage or migration. Having the config backup encrypted allows protection from unwanted access as well as the ability to restore the passwords previously stored inside the configuration. Consider using Backup Enterprise Manager's password protection to ensure lost passwords are recoverable, and separating Enterprise Manager and VBR in the event of a catastrophic outage. Also consider exporting the keyset to a secure location. Without this protection, lost passwords can cripple the ability to use backup files.

data.name: MssSum1
data.value: This table summarizes the different types and counts of infrastructure items that are manually added into the Veeam configuration by the user.

data.name: MssButton
data.value: Show details for detected infrastructure types & counts

data.name: BkpSrvButton
data.value: Show backup server summary and notes.

data.name: BkpSrvNotes1
data.value: • Ensure resource sizing of the Backup Server are adequate for the amount of concurrently running jobs that it manages. See Concurrency Table in this report. Note: if combining other roles or components onto the Backup Server host, resource sizing is additive (e.g., Backup Server + SQL + Proxy + Repository, etc.).

data.name: BkpSrvNotes2
data.value: • Ensure resource sizing of the SQL server are adequate

data.name: BkpSrvNotes3
data.value: • If using SQL Express, ensure it is not breaching the SQL Express hard-coded limits (e.g., # of CPUs, cores, memory, and database capacity). A slow, non-responsive, or error-laden backup server can often be a result of reaching these SQL limits.

data.name: BkpSrvNotes4
data.value: • Assigning data protection tasks to use the Default Proxy or Default Backup Repository components can lead to contention for backup server resources or other unintended traffic. Disabling, removing, and/or reassigning these away from the Backup Server may be desired in larger or distributed deployments.

data.name: BkpSrvNotes5
data.value: • Fast-performing disk is recommended for the log location, which by default is "%ProgramData%\\Veeam\\Backup"

data.name: BkpSrvNotes6
data.value: • DNS is a key component. Ensure DNS resolution both from the Backup Server, and for other systems to the Backup Server is functioning correctly. Other components in the environment should be able to resolve the Backup Server and other Veeam infrastructure components (e.g., Proxy, Repository) by FQDN. Both forward and reverse queries should be functional.

data.name: BkpSrvSummary1
data.value: The Backup Server (aka VBS or VBR Server) is the core component in the backup infrastructure that fills the role of the “configuration and control center”. The backup server performs all types of administrative activities, including: coordinating data protection & recovery tasks, task scheduling & resource allocation, and managing other backup infrastructure components.

data.name: BkpSrvSummary2
data.value: • Backup Servers run on Microsoft Windows

data.name: BkpSrvSummary3
data.value: • Stores data about the backup infrastructure, jobs, sessions, and other configuration data in either a local or remote SQL server. In a default installation, SQL Server Express is installed locally.

data.name: BkpSrvSummary4
data.value: • Has additional components deployed by default: Proxy, Repository

data.name: BstCpuTT
data.value: Detected physical cores on B&R server

data.name: BstPrxTT
data.value: Is backup server also a proxy?

data.name: BstRamTT
data.value: Detected total RAM on B&R server

data.name: BstRepTT
data.value: Is backup server also a repository or gateway server?

data.name: BstSqlCpuTT
data.value: SQL Server CPU (0 if shared with B&R Server)

data.name: BstSqlLocTT
data.value: Is SQL installed on the same server as B&R?

data.name: BstSqlRamTT
data.value: SQL Server RAM (0 if shared with B&R server)

data.name: BstWaTT
data.value: Is backup server also a WAN Accelerator?

data.name: Sbr7TT
data.value: Does the SOBR use Per-Machine backup files?

data.name: Sbr8TT
data.value: Type of capacity tier in use

data.name: Sbr11TT
data.value: Is capacity tier limited by total capacity?

data.name: Sbr12TT
data.value: Capacity Tier upload max capacity limit set by user

data.name: SbrSum0
data.value: o A scale-out backup repository ("SOBR") is a single logical repository namespace that consists of one or more underlying backup repositories, or "extents", enabling horizontal scaling across multiple tiers. Data lands on the SOBR's local Performance tier(s), which can be extended with object storage tiers for long-term and archive storage: capacity tier and archive tier.

data.name: SbrSum1
data.value: • SOBR can include multiple types of underlying extents, including: Window, Linux, NFS, SMB, Deduplication Appliances, and Object Storage

data.name: SbrNote0
data.value: • How many extents are in use? A large number of underlying extents can potentially lead to metadata management challenges and performance degradation. Discuss with your Veeam Engineer whether your extent count is satisfactory.

data.name: SbrNote1
data.value: • Is the "Performance" Placement Policy in use? If so, consider whether there was a specific reason or use case? "Data Locality" Placement Policy is more often the ideal policy for most deployments and use cases.

data.name: SbrNote2
data.value: • If using ReFS or XFS block cloning, the "Data Locality" placement policy is required in order to leverage block cloning ("Fast clone") functionality.

data.name: SbrNote3
data.value: • Is a gateway server in use for capacity tier copy/offload? Ensure that the gateway server has adequate resources to act as the funnel for all backups sent to this object storage repository.

data.name: SbrNote4
data.value: • The "Perform full backup when the required extent is offline" option (configured in the VBR console) should be considered carefully. It ensures that backups occur when the expected extent is offline, but with the trade off of additional space consumed for additional Active Full(s), and possible loss of storage efficiencies from volume-based block sharing technologies such as ReFS & XFS.

data.name: SbrNote5
data.value: • Is "Per-Machine" false? If so, consider whether there was a specific reason or use case for disabling it? Enabling this is the ideal policy for most deployments and use cases. Consult with your Veeam Engineer.

data.name: SbrNote6
data.value: • Is Infrequent Access storage tier used in conjunction with Veeam copy mode or Immutability on object storage? There are additional API calls associated with these processes that should be considered when budgeting access costs.

data.name: SbrExt1TT
data.value: SOBR in which the extent is joined.

data.name: SbrExt3TT
data.value: Physical CPU cores detected on repository server

data.name: SbrExt4TT
data.value: Total RAM detected on respository server

data.name: SbrExt5TT
data.value: Does the repository use Autmatica Gateway?

data.name: SbrExt6TT
data.value: Host/Gateway assigned if not set to use Automatic Gateway

data.name: SbrExt8TT
data.value: Detected free space based on last cached scan

data.name: SbrExt10TT
data.value: Calculated free space percentage (free space / total space)

data.name: SbrExt11TT
data.value: Does the repository decompress backup files before final storage?

data.name: SbrExt12TT
data.value: Does the repository align data blocks?

data.name: SbrExt13TT
data.value: Is the repository backed by rotated drives?

data.name: SbrExtSum0
data.value: •A SOBR is created by taking one, or many individual Veeam repositories (basic, or hardened) and placing them into the SOBR construct. The individual repositories comprising the SOBR are referred to as 'Extents'.

data.name: SbrExtSum1
data.value: •This section of the Health Check report details repository setting as they are configured in the Veeam Backup and Replication UI. These settings can affect, or help performance of a backup job.

data.name: SbrExtNote1
data.value: •This column is the max concurrent task setting allowed to a repository. It specifies the maximum allowed number of concurrent tasks for the backup repository. If this value is exceeded, Veeam Backup & Replication will not start a new task until one of current tasks finishes. For more information, see Limiting the Number of Concurrent Tasks.

data.name: SbrExtNote2
data.value: •To determine the number of tasks/cores needed for a backup repository(s) use the following formula:

data.name: SbrExtNote3
data.value: oThe number of proxy vCPU/cores / 3 = the number of needed repository tasks.

data.name: SbrExtNote4
data.value: •The setting should align with the next two columns: Cores, and RAM(GB)

data.name: SbrExtNote6
data.value: •This number is equal to the number of CPU cores in the repository server.

data.name: SbrExtNote8
data.value: •This number is equal to the amount of RAM in the repository server.

data.name: SbrExtNote9
data.value: •The amount of RAM should be 4x the number of cores.

data.name: SbrExtNote11
data.value: •Best practice is to maintain 20% free space in a repository. This is especially important if the SOBR extents are formatted with XFS/REFS file systems as the block cloning and spaceless synthetic backups need to have all the relevant Veeam backup files on the same disk. Free space is also important on other file systems as Veeam needs working space to create synthetic full backups.

data.name: SbrExtNote12
data.value: •In the General Options section of the VBR Console an alarm can be set to alert on repository low free disk space percentage.

data.name: SbrExtNote14
data.value: •For storage systems using a fixed block size, select the Align backup file data blocks check box. Veeam Backup & Replication will align VM data saved to a backup file at a 4 KB block boundary.

data.name: SbrExtNote15
data.value: •This setting also helps speed data transfer and uses less RAM when transferring data to a block-based repository

data.name: SbrExtNote16
data.value: •For block-based repositories in Veeam Backup and Replication v11 and newer this setting should be set to true.

data.name: Repo0TT
data.value: Total jobs assigned to the repository

data.name: Repo1TT
data.value: Does the repository use Per-VM/Machine backup files?

data.name: RepoSum0
data.value: •Standalone Repositories includes those not configured as part of a SOBR

data.name: RepoSum1
data.value: •This section of the Health Check report details repository setting as they are configured in the Veeam Backup and Replication UI. These settings can affect, or help performance of a backup job.

data.name: Prx1TT
data.value: Task limit assigned in proxy configuration.

data.name: Prx2TT
data.value: Physical CPU Cores detected (Hyperthreading is not counted)

data.name: Prx3TT
data.value: Total RAM detected on proxy host

data.name: Prx5TT
data.value: Transport mode specified in proxy configuration

data.name: Prx6TT
data.value: Is proxy allowed to fail over to NBD (network mode)

data.name: Prx8TT
data.value: Path specified for CDP Proxy cache

data.name: Prx9TT
data.value: Cache size specified for CDP Proxy

data.name: PrxSum0
data.value: Veeam proxies are a logical datamover component. There are two types of proxies: (Backup Proxies, CDP Proxies). Backup Proxies are further subdivided based on function or platform e.g. File Proxies for NAS-based backups, or different source hypervisors.

data.name: PrxSum1
data.value: • Backup proxies sit between source data (VMs or File Shares) and the backup repositories. Their role is to process backup jobs and deliver backup traffic to the repositories.

data.name: PrxSum2
data.value: o VM Backup proxies can leverage different transport modes.

data.name: PrxSum3
data.value: o File Backup proxies can backup source data from manual or automated snapshot paths for NFS, SMB, Enterprise NAS filers. (Note: Managed servers do not leverage File Backup Proxies)

data.name: PrxSum4
data.value: o Backup Proxies do not store or cache any data locally.

data.name: PrxSum5
data.value: • CDP proxies process CDP policies and operate as data movers between source and target VMware hosts.

data.name: PrxSum6
data.value: o CDP proxies require a local cache.

data.name: PrxNote0
data.value: • Review the “host” column and identify the host(s) that support multiple proxy roles:

data.name: PrxNote1
data.value: o Roles can be combined providing you allocate enough resources.

data.name: PrxNote2
data.value:  If roles are non-concurrent then allocate the max resources calculated across all supported roles.

data.name: PrxNote3
data.value:  If roles are concurrent then allocate enough resources for all roles

data.name: PrxNote4
data.value:  Keep in mind that CDP proxies are constantly active and transferring data, therefore it is imperative to “reserve” enough resources for its role and add what is necessary the combined role(s).

data.name: PrxNote7
data.value: o Flag CDP proxies with cache located on the C:\\ drive as a potential risk.

data.name: PrxNote8
data.value: • Compare assigned tasks and core count and identify oversubscription.

data.name: PrxNote9
data.value: • Confirm the RAM to core ratio is adequate.

data.name: PrxNote10
data.value: • Ensure there are enough resources for the base OS. (backup proxy, CDP proxy)

data.name: PrxNote11
data.value: • Check selected transport mode and highlight where failover to network mode is disabled when jobs are failing or where failover to network is enabled for jobs to run slower than expected (NBD traffic could flow through the wrong network).

data.name: PrxNote12
data.value: • Hyper-V off host proxies should match protected Hyper-V host versions.

data.name: ManSrv5TT
data.value: Total VMs detected on this host with associated backups

data.name: ManSrv6TT
data.value: Total VMs detected on this host without associated backups

data.name: ManSrv7TT
data.value: Total VMs detected on this host

data.name: ManSrv8TT
data.value: Is the server serving as a Veeam Proxy?

data.name: ManSrv9TT
data.value: Is the server serving as a Veeam Repository?

data.name: ManSrv10TT
data.value: Is the server serving as a Veeam WAN Accelerator?

data.name: ManSrvSum0
data.value: This lists all servers managed by Veeam that identify data sources (Hypervisors), backup infrastructure servers (windows, linux) and Veeam Backup for AWS/Azure/GCP appliances.

data.name: ManSrvNote0
data.value: • Review the API version column and ensure they are supported and meet the minimum requirements.

data.name: ManSrvNote1
data.value: • Highlight host supporting multiple roles and confirm enough resources are available to support them.

data.name: JobSum1TT
data.value: Total jobs detected of this type

data.name: JobSumSum0
data.value: Counts for all job types created on the Veeam Backup and replication server, and sum total of all jobs. The number of concurrently running jobs directly impacts the sizing and performance of the VBR server.

data.name: JobSumNote0
data.value: Be aware that some jobs, such as Backup Copy Jobs, are often configured to run continuously.

data.name: JobCon0TT
data.value: Hour of the day (24 hour format)

data.name: JobConSum0
data.value: The concurrency table is meant to serve as a heat map. Each hour of each day is represented. The number in each cell represents the highest calculated number of total concurrent running jobs within the specific hour. This data can be used to ensure more accurate VBR server sizing.

data.name: JobConNote1
data.value: Recommended Veeam backup server configuration is 1 CPU core (physical or virtual) and 4 GB RAM per 10 concurrently running jobs. Concurrent jobs include any running backup or replication jobs as well as any job with a continuous schedule such as backup copy jobs and tape jobs.

data.name: JobConNote2
data.value: The minimum recommendation is 2 CPU cores and 8 GB RAM.

data.name: JobConNote3
data.value: If the required resources exceed the current VBR CPU and RAM, job scheduling should be analyzed to minimize the number of concurrent jobs. If job scheduling changes are not possible, multiple VBR servers should be deployed, and jobs migrated to the new servers.

data.name: JobConNoteSqlTableNote0
data.value: It is recommended to install SQL Standard or Enterprise Edition if any of the following apply:

data.name: JobConNoteSqlTableNote1
data.value: • When protecting more than 500 servers. The max database size allowed by Express Edition is usually sufficient, so do not consider this a constraint. Veeam Backup & Replication console and job processing may however slow down as a result of CPU and RAM constraints on the SQL Server Express instance.

data.name: JobConNoteSqlTableNote2
data.value: • When using Files to Tape jobs extensively, the database may grow significantly, and the 10 GB limitation may be exceeded quickly.

data.name: JobConNoteSqlTableNote3
data.value: • When unable to configure an external staging server for use with Veeam Explorer for Microsoft SQL Server or Veeam Explorer for Microsoft SharePoint. When working with databases larger than 10 GB, SQL Server Express cannot mount the databases.

data.name: JobConNoteSqlTableNote4
data.value: • When databases are using advanced features of Microsoft SQL Server. Such as encryption or table partitioning, the licensing level of the staging server (local or remote) must match the level of the original instance.

data.name: TaskConSum0
data.value: The concurrency table is meant to serve as a heat map. Each hour of each day is represented. The number in each cell represents the highest calculated number of concurrent running Tasks within the specific hour. This data can be used to aid in job scheduling and proxy/repository task sizing.

data.name: TaskConNote0
data.value: Use this chart to check maximum concurrency. Each task here should be backed by 1 corresponding Proxy Task and 1/3 corresponding Repository Task.

data.name: RegSum0
data.value: This table details any Registry Keys that are different from the default keys set during a basic install of Veeam Backup & Replication. Specifically in HKLM\\SOFTWARE\\Veeam\\Veeam Backup and Replication

data.name: RegNote0
data.value: Because some registry keys are tied to bug fixes and/or other tweaks recommended for various reasons, it's best advised to consult your past support case emails and notes or contact your Veeam Engineer for any questions regarding keys shown here.

data.name: RegNote1
data.value: Some keys, such as LoggingLevel and other "Log" related keys are perfectly fine to adjust, if required, when following the corresponding KB Article.

data.name: JobInfo0TT
data.value: Job Name as shown in console

data.name: JobInfo1TT
data.value: Repository in which the job is targeting

data.name: JobInfo2TT
data.value: Actual size of source data for job

data.name: JobInfo3TT
data.value: Desired restore points as set in job config

data.name: JobInfo4TT
data.value: Does the job encrypt the backups?

data.name: JobInfoSum0
data.value: • Jobs define source data, destination, schedule, and advanced settings on handling that source data. There are multiple job types within Veeam Backup & Replication, including Backup, Backup Copy, CDP Policy, NAS Backup, and more. Not all job types will have data in every column.

data.name: JobInfoNote0
data.value: • Verify that the Restore Points and Schedule Options listed for the Job match with the source application’s required RPO. See Job Scheduling.

data.name: Jss0TT
data.value: Name of job as seen in B&R Console

data.name: Jss1TT
data.value: Number of items the job contains

data.name: Jss6TT
data.value: Success rate over detected sessions ( (Total Sessions - Fails + Retries) / Total Sessions * 100 )

data.name: Jss7TT
data.value: Average size of backup file in TB

data.name: Jss9TT
data.value: Average source data size in TB

data.name: Jss10TT
data.value: Largest source data size in TB

data.name: Jss11TT
data.value: Average calculated change rate for the job

data.name: Jss12TT
data.value: Total number of times the job was forced to wait for available resources

data.name: Jss14TT
data.value: Average duration job is waiting for available resources

data.name: JssSum0
data.value: This table is meant to detail the recent history of individual jobs over the last 7 or 30 days depending on specified period during collection.

data.name: JssNote0subhdr
data.value: Waiting for Resources / job session length issues:

data.name: JssNote1
data.value: • Scheduling jobs to start at different time slots will help to distribute resources and prevent the bottleneck that is a job waiting on available resources. (Ex. Instead of scheduling your jobs to all start at 8:00PM, start one job at 8:00, another at 8:30, and another at 9:00.)

data.name: JssNote2
data.value: • If resources allow, increase the number of concurrent tasks allowed on your proxies.See How to set max concurrent tasks.

data.name: JssNote3
data.value: o If your backup proxy does not have adequate resources to increase tasks, and it is a virtual machine, you should consider increasing the amount of CPU and RAM available to the proxy.

data.name: JssNote4
data.value: o If adding resources to existing proxies is not an options, consider deploying additional backup proxies from within “Backup Infrastructure->Backup Proxies”

data.name: JssNote5
data.value: • Make sure that your backup job or replication job is selecting the correct proxies by viewing the job session statistics in the VBR Console.

data.name: JssNote6
data.value: • Investigate backup job performance. If specific jobs are taking longer to process than normal, check for warnings, compare the bottleneck statistics to previous jobs sessions, and try to isolate the problem to a specific proxy, repository, host, or datastore.

data.name: JssNote7
data.value: o Move larger VMs / servers to their own job and schedule to ensure conflict does not occur with faster completing job's backup window (schedule these jobs before all other jobs or after all other jobs, for example)

data.name: JssNote8
data.value: • Separate NAS Proxies, Cache Repos, and Repositories from VM proxies and VM and Agent Repositories

data.name: JssNote9
data.value: • Use Static Gateways and Mount Serversif possible to offload resources consumption required for synthetic operations, SOBR offload processing, backup copy jobs, and other tasks.

data.name: JssNote10
data.value: • If appropriate,review Architecture Guidelines for deduplicating storage systems.

data.name: v365NavValue0
data.value: Summary of license and global settings.

data.name: v365NavValue1
data.value: Summary of protected and unprotected users.

data.name: v365NavValue3
data.value: Details on the disks attached to the VB365 Server.

data.name: v365NavValue4
data.value: Details on proxies added to the current VB365 Server.

data.name: v365NavValue5
data.value: Details on reposiories added to the current VB365.

data.name: v365NavValue7
data.value: Summary of security settings relevant to VB365.

data.name: v365NavValue8
data.value: Summary of Role Based Access Control settings.

data.name: v365NavValue10
data.value: Details on organizations protected by VB365.

data.name: v365NavValue11
data.value: Details on jobs configued on this VB365 Server.
